text: Welcome to all of you, my little rascals who rape hens...
People often say that I am vulgar in my videos,
so, this time, I'll mind my words and speak politely.
The delicacy of my way of speaking will render this review as understandable as possible to all of those who cannot stand rude speeches.
However, before starting this test on Sekiro, you've probably heard that
"Article 13" has been voted with 348 voices supporting the article
against 274 voices that dismissed it.
To sum up, "Article 13", that has become "Article 17",
demands that contents on the internet are filtered as soon as they come out.
Whatever ... everyone will get to understand that this is quite impossible to implement;
however, instead of complaining and trying to explain that this is bullshit to people that do not even have Internet
- I am talking about European deputes...
I'll provide a solution to you: use PureVPN
that will locate your IP Address anywhere you want it in the world.
You'll benefit, for example, of the American Netflix catalogue,
way more furnished than the French one.
Anyway, in regards of the moronic politics we have in Europe,
we'll have to use a VPN. In the description box, you'll find a link for a one-month free trial - give yourself a treat!
With this, it's time for my test on Sekiro.
Who's there?         - *BURP*                                                (translator's note: in French, pun on "c'est qui?'" (SE-KI) that is, here, translated literally)
Sekiro is a game developed by From Software ...
the hell-made video game developer that is behind the Dark Souls series,
a video game series largely acknowledged by all masochist gamers.
To briefly sum up the game to those few who wouldn't know Dark Souls,
it's a challenging game in which you will die plenty of times
while fighting enemies that will make hell out of your life,
demanding you to surpass yourself in order to go further,
which will result in your self-contentment that is similar to an orgasm.
Of course, tiny little Sekiro is made along the same lines as its spiritual father;
so, it has to be said: there will be hell to pay.
However, we're very far from a Dark Souls' cold, dejected and forsaken kingdom
and which soundtrack would leave the happiest of you weeping.
*To die
that's
that's such a real fun*
No, the world in Sekiro is, well, not so funny either as it takes place in medieval Japan during the Sengoku period
- and I spoil you a Dragon Ball joke.
But, in general, it was an era during which
many clans slaughtered each other.
The current clan that dominates in game is the Ashina clan,
that has actually existed, by the way,
and you'll play a character that everyone names "Wolf",
a Shinobi in charge of protecting Kuro, the Prince and heir
and last survivor of a long lineage. Your character is bond to the Prince's protection through a ritual ordained by Kuro's father.
And, of course, even though the Prince is a 10-year-old kid,
you follow his orders like a puppy:
"So, go make me some hot chocolate and then we'll play fortnite.
- Yes, Sir. And, afterwards, you may spit on me if you lose."
"I'm dumb."
Besides this, yes, I play in French.
Not everyone likes to read subtitles when playing, not everyone can understand
the original dialogues. And for me, Japan is more than just animes and mangas.
That's why I don't have to pretend to understand Japanese so as to show off. Anyway,
I like Japan, subtitles piss me off and those who judge me, go suck dicks in Hell.
Oh darn ... I said no swearing. Oh, to hell with it.
In any case, I'm going to discuss the gameplay so I wouldn't have been able to stop my insults.
So, the first challenge you'll face
are the game's Terms of Services.
I agree or disagree?
Goddammit, I always make the wrong choice!
No, I'm kidding, I'm not that bad - I went a bit further in the game.
Want to see my first steps in Sekiro?
That was just because I wanted to see what happens if I die.
Because, you know, I'm a Pro Gamer. I'm paid to play video games.
Thus I was certain to play through the game easily. Unfortunately, contrary to Dark Souls,
you can't play as a magician specialised in fire. No, you have to play with your saber
and your very Shinobi arm that enables you to use tools,
like shurikens, a hatchet,
a hat, a fan, my dick, ravens
and other stupid things. Besides, of course, your character can develop
its attack power in using trophies that you obtain when you kill a boss.
You can also level-up your defense power
and your vitality that is, as it matters, a joke as
most attacks will kill you in one blow or two, when you're lucky.
Therefore, one may think that because of such a challenge, the game has
to be perfectly fair and that it efficiently answers
to the gamer's moves so that the gamer can focus on his battles
and not to get killed due to technical issues.
It'd be downright disgusting to let the players play a character
as delicate while you could die of issues due
to the camera. It'd be downright disgusting not to see your
enemy because the camera films a wall.
It'd be downright disgusting if the camera would be squeezed against the wall
focusing so much on your enemy that you could not even see your own character's moves.
It'd be downright disgusting if such a challenging game
would let you have a bug in the scenery
and which would jeopardize your life when infiltrating somewhere. It'd be downright disgusting
to have pop up a tutorial while in the middle of a fight. You know,
right when you have to defend yourself from a blow.
It'd be downright disgusting if sometimes assassinations
highlighted with a bright red circle and quasi-obligatory
for some boss fights just don't work.
It'd be downright disgusting to randomly lose the targeting on your enemy
which would prevent you to block a blow and,
finally, it'd be downright disgusting that enemies could strike you through walls.
That would be especially idiotic for such a challenging game.
Goddammit, I agree to say that the game is challenging which
is a very good point. However, that the game lacks technical accuracy,
that's a no way. Whatever the game, to die because of bugs
or technical issues, that's the worst that could happen to a gamer.
But then, I still finished the game but I wasted quite a bit of time
in starting from scratch some boss fights because the camera
lost its focus or I lost targeting on my enemies. Even if this happens not that often.
I admit, I mostly died because I lacked knowledge on how to play certain boss fights.
But then, that's what I want! I want to die because I did wrong.
And, even more so, I want to win because I played well. Like, for example,
against this boss who's considered one of the game's most challenging.
Yes, indeed, he who's paddling in a pool of acid. Comes in handy
as while he very slowly dies, you can
take your dog for a walk, wash some dishes, make love to your wife,
take your dishes for a walk, make love to your dog, do the woman or
every other activity that roughly takes 10 minutes. And yes, I already see some commenting:
"you could have fought him honorably."
Listen well, I play as a Shinobi, not as a Samurai. Honor is achieved
when a mission is a success regardless of the means used to reach the end.
That said, to be honest, to see a boss commit suicide
in front of you, that's way less alluring. See it this way, there's not much
self-contentment. Now, let's talk about stealth in the game.
That's very important to start a clash: stealth enables you to one-shot
regular enemies while it also takes off 1 life of a mini-boss who
are, sometimes, more challenging than a real boss.
Stealth also enables you to highlight all the details the game developers accorded
to the game's AI ...
... - non-existent and thoroughly stupid.
Seriously, between enemies on whom you throw some china right in the face but who
are not sure that there's something behind the wall ... and the others on whom
I throw plenty in the face and who don't move ...
and those who are completely blind.
Well, after all, the game's developers cannot program a camera,
so then program and manage an AI ... pfff.
Truth be told, to be stealthy will come in
handy against major and massive enemies,
at least as massive as my passion for video games
- of course. Even though this snake roughly has the same size as ma phal -
"Those who most speak about it, do the least." Ha!
Nice argument for virgins. Your mother often speaks about her dick?
No, so according to you, she's quite the shameless woman?
Well, piss off. Of course, the game hasn't only flaws and
some boss fights are actually really challenging - you die and you learn.
This game tries to push you in a tight corner and its aim
is to get you to try harder so that you earn the right to get to the next step.
This game doesn't offer you everything on a plate; you'll have to deserve it.
Challenges are no malleable parts of the gameplay;
they're main parts of the gameplay. And contrary to Dark Souls,
there is no easy way to approach the game. You'll have to fight in close-range
with a katana.
No luck for those used in playing as magicians. Indeed,
you can no longer easily walk through the game while daring enjoying it.
Here, you'll have to pay hell as everybody has to. But contrary to the others,
are you up to the challenge? Will you be one of the few who finished the game,
or will you belong to those people who
bought the game but have found it so hard (like my dick) that they mark it
0/20 on jeuxvideo.com out of revenge?
LOL. Too bad at it, noobs? To crappy to play the game?
"I love the game, but I'm tired of dying several times in a row.
As long as there's no easy game mode, the 0/20 is gonna stay.
Yes, I rage, but it's legitimate." Of course, what a
good idea to implement an easy game mode and thus rewrite the game's principles.
Really, I'll never understand that.
All year-long you have games that are easy and accessible for the greater part
of those that are released. Why, for the only game that gives you
some challenge, you absolutely want to level it down
and empty it of its very essence so that your lack of
determination to get further into the game
turns it into a game so similar to the many others. Really, if you're tired of playing it,
go watch the game on Games Movie Land. If the game's developers
conceived the game in such a way, there must be a reason why. But after all,
I understand why some rage because they bought the game 70€
and end up stuck in the game, unable to move on, because, well...
they either missed something or they're too bad at it. But, move your ass,
once and for all, instead of begging for an easy game mode.
I think you're to used at having control other things and that you're
as capricious as a child. Unfortunately, the game is PEGI18.
With this, let's get to the section: the press.
And we'll start with gameblog.fr that marks the game 9/10.
Well, the + points: "it's very exhilarating to finish the game."
And, "fight mechanism that are absorbing and exhilarating."
What's up with the word exhilarating, dammit? What did it to you? Leave that word be.
"Magnificent settings." Magnificent, magnificent ...
It's nice but not much more, don't overdo it.
At the same time, I wonder what you consider ugly at gameblog.fr.
Because, yes, you know how to make hypocrisy magnificent! And I think that video game producers
must find that very exhilarating. Ha.
Now, let's talk about jeuxactu.com that marked the game 17/20.
The + points: "Japanese voices that are authoritative."
What? What new language is "authoritative Japanese"?
For the - points: "not a very witty AI." Really, not very witty?
A comatose oyster would act more naturally.
Don't be afraid of words... This is a bullshit AI. Yes, BULLSHIT,
Besides, I don't have much to say about the press
because everyone says the same. To sum up: the game is challenging and it's nice
but the AI and the camera are shit. Therefore, I'll now give my mark
in concluding on some gamer's hypocrisy towards Sekiro.
This review is a very good example.
"While used to challenges and tough games,
this game is too tough
and more than one player will recoil from it. We like challenges but not hard-challenges."
Listen well, either you like challenges
or you don't like them. I'm tired of those players who describe themselves as
challengers so as to justify what cannot be justified. I really
understand that gamers don't like the game because of its difficulty. That's not an issue.
But don't put the blame on someone else because you give up.
You just didn't try hard enough, that's it. To conclude,
the issue lies not in the game, it's you ... / 20!
